RHD-1855
New York City,
April 23,1906.
John G. Neihardt, Esq.,
Bancroft, Nebraska.
My dear Neihardt:
div1.p: If you could live an hour of my life you would then know what a terrible thing it is to die. I suppose I get more real enjoyment out of things, every twenty-four hours than you do in twenty-four days. The one obstruction to unbridled mental peace is a note of earnestness. The moment anything strikes you as really important or serious, that moment multiplied by ten becomes a task.

I am a sort of socialist in my own way. But it depends upon a good many external things, and I have no regular internal policy. I find it much more satisfactory to be affected by every wind that blows. I am an anarchist in the morning, a socialist at noon, a free-thinker at sunset, and a penitent at midnight — but you can bet I get my sleep between that and the dawning so that the next day looks just as fresh.

The only way they could have put Shelley on the blink was to have called him Mr. Shelley, although the effort to annhilate Shakespear Shakespeare by prefixing the given name "Bill" was a failure. Keates might just as well have been a baseball pitcher. I believe he did throw some pretty good curves in his time.

While we are on the subject of mutual confidences, I suppose I can say to you that life to me is more or less of a union job anyhow. I will stay with any combination that gives me high wages and good results. Don't you get the pin-headed idea, out there on the flat lands, with the wire grass tripping you up, that I am a "city-ridden" wretch. I can fall backwards into any chair or down into a bunch of palms that are just about as broad and fascinating as any in a tropical garden, and I can get any perfume that was ever wafted across the noses by simply sitting down and thinking hard of a thousand places I have been and am going to again.
I do not believe in mirages, dreams, real-estate maps or railroad guides. You've got to show it to me. I want to be lead to it.

I am glad that your family had a "hell of a fight" to get into the open air. Mine had a "hell of a fight" to get back from it. I was crawling around in the bunch grass of Nebraska when your parents were figuring out whether they would rather have a boy or a girl.

I guess that the best way for both of us is to proceed along the particular route that seems less wearying to our moral feet. I am sure we shall both bring up in the same place, no matter whether the road be long or short. The only difference is this: one of us will steal axle-grease for the trips the other will borrow it — (but in either case the fellow who lends it is likely to be dead when the debt is paid.)

I am glad to know that there is a prospect of seeing you someday in New York. I enclose a portrait of myself on

a yacht. You will see that I am not nearly so old a party as you conceived me to be. If you have any difficulty locating me, let me say that I am the gentleman with the black coat. The other party is not me. I am having a similar picture taken in a blue coat, which I will send later — a profile.
